nodes.bodyText: We could go one step further with this and have S3 users only use the Default Credentials Provider and never the static creds provider, it would make this a bit cleaner (if S3, use Default, if GCP use Static), the only caveat would be S3 users would be forced to set up their creds the AWS way and would break any existing users that use the old config.
Yeah, let's not break users.
These need to be removed from config table as well.

This will break users using these properties. This is probably worth the trade off but we need to call it out in the release notes and directly give a few users we know who are using it a heads up.

That makes sense.  The two users I've spoken to/heard from mentioned the existing solution was not enough for what they were looking to do, so I'm hopeful that few are actually using these properties, but definitely need to get the word out.

Don't compare enums by string or by equals(), you can just use downloaderProperties.getCloudProvider() == CommonDownloaderProperties.CloudProvider.GCP. This way avoids a possible NPE, is type safe and faster.
Fixed.

nodes.bodyText:
I've done it in Docker Compose using a volume in the importer that points to my local credentials: ~/.aws/:/root/.aws:ro.  You could do something similar in Kubernetes with a secret, or you can directly enter the keys as secrets in Kubernetes (AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID and AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY).  I like this breakdown.
There are also a host of other ways of doing it, one of the comments on the last issue is using this as they are running in AWS's Kubernetes solution, EKS.
I can add a little documentation for the simplest ways to get it running in Kubernetes and Docker (point to existing credentials file or directly add the keys as environment variables), beyond that it would probably be overkill.
